comments:

I cannot reproduce on 3.2 M3.  I assume you are using the 3.1.1 release?
Exactly, "3.1.1", as in the Version field

I have not been able to reproduce that exception, but I can make weird things
happen with similar steps:

1) Create simple project "Source"
2) Add folder "f" to Source
3) Close project Source
4) Create simple project "Target"
5) Create linked folder f in Target that points to the dir of f in Source
6) Add a file to /Target/f

-> In the Navigator, a child is added to Source even though it is a closed project!

Since my failure is different, I have entered bug 116517 for it.  Can you give
steps to reproduce your failure? Moving back to inbox.

Just to make sure we are talking about the same version: my build id is
M20050929-0840. In a clean workspace, I've been able to reproduce this bug only 
in the following case:

1. Create a new project "target"
2. Import | Existing projects into workspace - import any plugin (let's call 
it "plugin") containing a nested folder (let's call it "nf") from a different 
workspace
3. Close the imported "plugin" that has appeared in your new workspace
4. For the "target" project choose: New | Folder | Link to folder in the file 
system - select a nested folder "nf" in the original "plugin" 
location, "Finish", and see the message.

However each time the error occurs, a warning appears at the top of the dialog:
"Location <plugin>\<nf> may overlap another resource. This can cause unexpected 
side-effects."

Thanks for the steps - I can reproduce it now in 3.1.1.  I definitely can't reproduce it in 3.2 stream though.  We typically only release fixes in the 3.1.x branch for critical bugs - the risk of instability is high because there is a much smaller testing window and fewer testers for maintenance releases.  I wouldn't consider this a critical bug due to the obscurity of the test case and the low impact of the failure.  Unless you consider the impact to be high, I will just marked this bug as fixed in the 3.2 stream.
Closing. This has already been fixed in the 3.2 stream.
